   19986+A<>numbers. In referring to these, a small superior number is used, and designates the
EQ 19986+B<>numbers. In referring to these, a small superior number is used, and designates the
   19987+A<>(typographical) paragraph as counted from the last lettered or numbered subsection.

   19991+A<><head>SIGNS.</head>

   19992+A<><p>The root-sign (£) is prefixed to roots and quasi-roots to catch the eye or as an
EQ 19992+B<><p>The root-sign (£) is prefixed to roots and quasi-roots to catch the eye or as an
   19993+A<>abbreviation. It is also set before denominative verb-stems, although these are of
EQ 19993+B<>abbreviation. It is also set before denominative verb-stems, although these are of
   19994+A<>course in no sense roots.</p>
EQ 19994+B<>course in no sense roots.</p>
   19995+A<><p>The plus-sign (+) is set before prepositions with which verbs appear in composition
EQ 19995+B<><p>The plus-sign (+) is set before prepositions with which verbs appear in composition
   19996+A<>and before certain other elements used as prefixes.</p>
EQ 19996+B<>and before certain other elements used as prefixes.</p>
   19997+A<><p>A star (*) signifies that the word or stem or root to which it is prefixed does not
EQ 19997+B<><p>A star (*) signifies that the word or stem or root to which it is prefixed does not
   19998+A<>actually occur in that form.</p>
EQ 19998+B<>actually occur in that form.</p>
   19999+A<><p>A half-parenthesis on its side (_) is used to show that two vowels, which, for
EQ 19999+B<><p>A half-parenthesis on its side (_) is used to show that two vowels, which, for
   20000+A<>the sake of clearness, are printed with hiatus in violation of the rules of euphonic
EQ 20000+B<>the sake of clearness, are printed with hiatus in violation of the rules of euphonic
   20001+A<>combination, should be combined according to those rules.</p>
EQ 20001+B<>combination, should be combined according to those rules.</p>
   20002+A<><p>A hyphen is sometimes used to avoid the repetition of an element of a compound;
EQ 20002+B<><p>A hyphen is sometimes used to avoid the repetition of an element of a compound;
   20003+A<>thus in the article {@loka,@} p. 235, {@para-@} stands for {@para-loka.@}</p>
EQ 20003+B<>thus in the article {@loka,@} p. 235, {@para-@} stands for {@para-loka.@}</p>

   20005+A<>as English {%y.%} A very few Slavic and Lithuanian words occur, in which the actual or

   20009+A<><p>It is hoped that most of these, if not all, will be found self-explaining. To preclude

   20010+A<>any misunderstanding, however, a complete list of the abbreviations is given below, p. 293.</p>

EQ 20011+B<><p>But certain abbreviations and words are used in an arbitrary way and require

   20142+A<>show the beginner in what category of compounds this word belongs. So 1290 states

   23223+A<>quite definitely known. According to the author's fancy, it unites in itself all

   23224+A<>stories as does the ocean all rivers, and he therefore calls it the ‘Ocean of the

EQ 23229+B<>to mean ‘surges.’ The work contains about 22,000 distichs, that is, about one- [Page332-a+ 68]
